speaker: Rudy Giuliani
vclaim: "Democracy is kind of falling on each other to see who can raise taxes faster. It looks like they're gonna raise taxes anywhere between 20 and 30 percent."
date: stated on July 30, 2007 in a speech in Laconia, New Hampshire.:
title: He plays fast and loose with numbers.
text: It is not quite clear from the context whether Giuliani is talking about democratic or democratic presidential candidates in Congress. But that doesn't really matter, especially since many candidates in the democratic sphere are in the Senate or the House of Representatives. In both cases, Giuliani is right that Democrats are open to letting some of the 2001 tax cuts end, which would raise taxes on those affected. Most candidates for the Democratic Presidency said that they wanted to renew some of those tax cuts, which were due to end in 2010. However, they also indicated that they would prefer to allow tax cuts to end, which in their view would unfairly benefit rich Americans. The tax rate on household income in excess of $200,000 will return to higher levels, as will taxes on capital gains, profits and property. But is that a 20% to 30% increase? By Samantha Butterman (January 17, 2021) to defend his claim, Juliani's campaign refers to a report by the Congressional Budget Office showing a 31% increase in revenue from 2006 to 2011 if all tax cuts are allowed to end. There are two problems with this. First of all, Democrats do not advocate the elimination of all tax cuts for 2001. Second, Juliani's reasoning is that the increase in revenue is the same as the increase in tax. If this is the standard, more than President Bush ' s 2008 budget, released in February, it includes a 29 percent tax increase over the same period, too. No, that's not enough.
